awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Social Construction of Legal Exclusion in Slums
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how legal exclusion is socially constructed in legally recognized vs. non-recognized slum settlements.  Extensive research has demonstrated that residents of slum settlements globally have considerably worse outcomes on key social indicators, including poverty, employment conditions, and exposure to violence, than formally housed urban populations.  Despite the recognition that legal status has significant impacts on the socioeconomic conditions of slum residents, little is known about why governments withhold official recognition and deny access to life-supporting infrastructure and residential security for slum residents.  This research investigates how legal exclusion is constructed--as a political and bureaucratic entity, as a geographic and social reality, and as individual lived experience.  It is also designed to explain how conditions vary in communities with different degrees of legal recognition and access.

The project's three research aims are to identify the multi-level factors that produce the legal exclusion experienced by residents of non-recognized slums; demonstrate how legal exclusion is experienced as both a collective and individual level phenomenon that shapes the wellbeing of slum residents; and disentangle the effects of legal exclusions from other, more widely studied aspects of informal settlements, by comparing slum settlements with different administrative and legal contexts. The multi-level research design builds on insights from ethnographic research on social exclusion and political action in slums showing that legal exclusion is not only produced at the macro-level through policy and public discourse, but also at the community-level through negotiations with local administrators, police officers, and service delivery workers; and at the micro-level within the inner lives and subjective experiences of slum residents. This approach is rooted in longstanding efforts in sociology to integrate macro theories of social structure with micro-level analyses of social action to explain collective and individual outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand the health and social impacts (and the social construction) of legal exclusion in urban slum communities in Mumbai, India. Most of the field research was conducted in the Kaula Bandar community, which is “non-notified,” or not recognized by the government. Some of the field research was conducted in Dharavi and Mandala, which are at least partly “notified” or recognized by the government. All data were collected by youth who live in the Kaula Bandar slum community in a participatory manner. Data collection happened despite multiple lockdowns during 2020 and 2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The outcomes from this project so far can be divided into data and research papers.

 

In terms of data, this project was very successful in generating both ethnographic observations and in-depth life history interviews. All of this data was recorded and then has been transcribed into English, coded by at least two student researchers using Dedoose software, and then reconciled under the guidance of the principal investigators. These fully coded ethnographic observations and in-depth life history interviews represent a unparalleled and unique dataset for ongoing analyses and research products. Specifically, the project generated 372 ethnographic observations and 58 in-depth life history interviews, all of which are translated, coded, and reconciled.

 

With regard to research outputs, several papers are planned, including some that will focus on the relationship of Kaula Bandar residents with government authorities (led by Dr. Weinstein) and on the subjective experience of health of Kaula Bandar residents and how this is shaped by legal exclusion (led by Dr. Subbaraman). Two research outputs have been produced so far, as listed below:

 

Lubeck-Schricker M, Patil-Deshmukh A, Murthy SL, Chaubey MD, Boomkar B, Shaikh N, Shitole T, Eliasziw M, Subbaraman R. Divided infrastructure: legal exclusion and water inequality in an urban slum in Mumbai, India. Environ Urban. 2023 Apr;35(1):178-198. doi: 10.1177/09562478221121737. Epub 2023 Jan 12. PMID: 37275771; PMCID: PMC10237587.

 

Dev S, Duval J, Galivanche A, Shitole T, Sawant K, Shitole S, Patil-Deshmukh A, Lincoln A, Subbaraman R, Weinstein L. Spatializing stigma-power: Mental health impacts of spatial stigma in a legally-excluded settlement in Mumbai, India. PLOS Glob Public Health. 2023 Jul 20;3(7):e0001026. doi: 10.1371/journal.pgph.0001026. PMID: 37471352; PMCID: PMC10358916.
